article.title: Equation of state of polydisperse hard-disk mixtures in the high-density regime

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 primarily illustrate regarding the approximation of the third virial coefficient (B3) for the examined hard-disk mixtures?
choices: B<sub>3</sub><sup>PP</sup> consistently overestimates B<sub>3</sub> by a significant margin, particularly at lower values.
B<sub>3</sub><sup>PP</sup> consistently underestimates B<sub>3</sub>, with the discrepancy increasing as B<sub>3</sub> decreases.
B<sub>3</sub><sup>PP</sup> provides a very close approximation to B<sub>3</sub> even when B<sub>3</sub> is significantly smaller than the monocomponent value.
There is no clear relationship between B<sub>3</sub><sup>PP</sup> and B<sub>3</sub>, with the scatter plot showing a random distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference is observed between the behavior of mixtures TH1 and TH2 compared to other mixtures in Figure 4(b) in the metastable region (φ<sub>eff</sub> > 0.7)?
choices: Mixtures TH1 and TH2 exhibit a sharp decrease in compressibility factor, indicating a transition to a less dense state.
Mixtures TH1 and TH2 display crystallization effects, causing their curves to follow a trend similar to the monocomponent fluid.
Mixtures TH1 and TH2 show a significantly higher compressibility factor compared to other mixtures and the monocomponent fluid.
Mixtures TH1 and TH2 show no significant deviation from the general trend of collapsing onto the monocomponent curve.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using Equation (19) over Equation (14) for inferring the monocomponent compressibility factor (Zs) as illustrated in Figure 6?
choices: Equation (19) requires a smaller computational cost as it utilizes the readily available packing fraction of the mixture.
Equation (19) allows for the inference of Zs at the same packing fractions as the polydisperse mixture, leading to less noisy results.
Equation (19) avoids the numerical evaluation of the scaling parameter λ, simplifying the calculation process.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Equation (30) provide an estimate for, specifically in the context of hard-disk mixtures?
choices: The maximum packing fraction achievable for a given polydisperse mixture before the onset of crystallization.
The jamming packing fraction (φ<sub>J</sub>) of a polydisperse mixture based on the random close-packing fraction (φ<sub>rcp</sub>) of the monocomponent system.
The critical packing fraction at which a polydisperse mixture transitions from a stable fluid to a metastable fluid.
The effective packing fraction (φ<sub>eff</sub>) of a polydisperse mixture that corresponds to a given packing fraction (φ) of the monocomponent system.
